I joined Code Like a Girl in 2018 after attending their inaugural Adelaide event, with hundreds of people crammed into a cosy venue. I was so energised by the vision that Ally Watson OAM had for the future of the tech industry. I started by putting in a few hours a week as Education Lead in South Australia, and my role soon evolved to SA State Director. In 2020, I was offered a full-time role as Lead Technologist and joined the Leadership Team in 2024. The company went through several iterations during my time there, each bringing opportunities to work with amazing new people and innovative programs.Together, we accomplished things Iâ€™ll always be proud of.Led by some incredible program managers, we grew the wildly successful internship program, which has placed over 200 women and gender-diverse individuals in paid internships, and continues to place even more.I upskilled and led the full-stack development efforts for our internship placement platform/app, which centralised program data, automated many previously manual workflows, and provided easy interfaces for interns and hiring partners to manage their information.In just a few short months, we developed and released the School of Code for online coding education, seizing the opportunity to provide accessible learning during lockdowns.I taught hundreds of kids and adults through in-person workshops, code camps, tutor groups, and online sessions. One online workshop had over 400 attendees, we even crashed CodeSandbox ğŸ˜… I trained government employees to use Python for improving their workflows. I helped develop curriculums in C#, JavaScript, React.js, and Node.js. I facilitated panels, events, and webinarsâ€”including a session on the main stage at the Virtual Engineers Summit. Sadly, my role ended at the close of 2024. DEIB work is often underfunded, making it challenging to sustain engineering roles in this space. I get it. I'm grateful. Iâ€™ll always be part of this community. Code Like a Girl isnâ€™t just a company; itâ€™s a network, a movement, a heartbeat. I have met some of my dearest friends through Code Like a Girl. Iâ€™ll continue to show up as a community advocate, a mentor, and a fan.BUT a new adventure is beginning soon. Iâ€™m excited. ğŸ‘€ Watch this space.

ğŸš€ TECO Acquires Malaysia's NCL Energy to Enter Southeast Asia's Data Center MEP Engineering Market ğŸŒExciting News! ğŸ‰ TECO has officially signed an acquisition agreement in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, with NCL Energy Sdn Bhd. By acquiring an 80% stake in NCL, TECO becomes the largest shareholder, marking a significant milestone in our expansion into Malaysia's MEP engineering market for data centers and renewable energy."This acquisition aligns with TECO's strategy of focusing on the Southeast Asian market and demonstrates our long-term commitment to the Malaysian market," said Chairman Li. With NCL's experienced team, TECO will swiftly obtain the necessary licenses and workforce. NCL founder Dato' Ng Keng Hiong expressed his honor in joining the TECO Group. This investment not only recognizes NCL's management team but also aims to expand our capabilities in large-scale projects. TECO is excited to seize market opportunities and fulfill our vision of electrification, intelligence, and green energy in Southeast Asia. ğŸ’šğŸŒŸLast but not least, TECO is looking for talented individuals to join our team in Malaysia!ğŸŒŸ We are actively hiring for various positions in our Malaysia IDC market. I joined Code Like a Girl in 2018 after attending their inaugural Adelaide event, with hundreds of people crammed into a cosy venue. I was so energised by the vision that Ally Watson OAM had for the future of the tech industry. I started by putting in a few hours a week as Education Lead in South Australia, and my role soon evolved to SA State Director. In 2020, I was offered a full-time role as Lead Technologist and joined the Leadership Team in 2024. The company went through several iterations during my time there, each bringing opportunities to work with amazing new people and innovative programs.Together, we accomplished things Iâ€™ll always be proud of.Led by some incredible program managers, we grew the wildly successful internship program, which has placed over 200 women and gender-diverse individuals in paid internships, and continues to place even more.I upskilled and led the full-stack development efforts for our internship placement platform/app, which centralised program data, automated many previously manual workflows, and provided easy interfaces for interns and hiring partners to manage their information.In just a few short months, we developed and released the School of Code for online coding education, seizing the opportunity to provide accessible learning during lockdowns.I taught hundreds of kids and adults through in-person workshops, code camps, tutor groups, and online sessions. One online workshop had over 400 attendees, we even crashed CodeSandbox ğŸ˜… I trained government employees to use Python for improving their workflows. I helped develop curriculums in C#, JavaScript, React.js, and Node.js. I facilitated panels, events, and webinarsâ€”including a session on the main stage at the Virtual Engineers Summit. Sadly, my role ended at the close of 2024. DEIB work is often underfunded, making it challenging to sustain engineering roles in this space. I get it. I'm grateful. Iâ€™ll always be part of this community. Code Like a Girl isnâ€™t just a company; itâ€™s a network, a movement, a heartbeat. I have met some of my dearest friends through Code Like a Girl. Iâ€™ll continue to show up as a community advocate, a mentor, and a fan.BUT a new adventure is beginning soon. Iâ€™m excited. ğŸ‘€ Watch this space.

I joined Code Like a Girl in 2018 after attending their inaugural Adelaide event, with hundreds of people crammed into a cosy venue. I was so energised by the vision that Ally Watson OAM had for the future of the tech industry. I started by putting in a few hours a week as Education Lead in South Australia, and my role soon evolved to SA State Director. In 2020, I was offered a full-time role as Lead Technologist and joined the Leadership Team in 2024. The company went through several iterations during my time there, each bringing opportunities to work with amazing new people and innovative programs.Together, we accomplished things Iâ€™ll always be proud of.Led by some incredible program managers, we grew the wildly successful internship program, which has placed over 200 women and gender-diverse individuals in paid internships, and continues to place even more.I upskilled and led the full-stack development efforts for our internship placement platform/app, which centralised program data, automated many previously manual workflows, and provided easy interfaces for interns and hiring partners to manage their information.In just a few short months, we developed and released the School of Code for online coding education, seizing the opportunity to provide accessible learning during lockdowns.I taught hundreds of kids and adults through in-person workshops, code camps, tutor groups, and online sessions. One online workshop had over 400 attendees, we even crashed CodeSandbox ğŸ˜… I trained government employees to use Python for improving their workflows. I helped develop curriculums in C#, JavaScript, React.js, and Node.js. I facilitated panels, events, and webinarsâ€”including a session on the main stage at the Virtual Engineers Summit. Sadly, my role ended at the close of 2024. DEIB work is often underfunded, making it challenging to sustain engineering roles in this space. I get it. I'm grateful. Iâ€™ll always be part of this community. Code Like a Girl isnâ€™t just a company; itâ€™s a network, a movement, a heartbeat. I have met some of my dearest friends through Code Like a Girl. Iâ€™ll continue to show up as a community advocate, a mentor, and a fan.BUT a new adventure is beginning soon. Iâ€™m excited. ğŸ‘€ Watch this space.

I joined Code Like a Girl in 2018 after attending their inaugural Adelaide event, with hundreds of people crammed into a cosy venue. I was so energised by the vision that Ally Watson OAM had for the future of the tech industry. I started by putting in a few hours a week as Education Lead in South Australia, and my role soon evolved to SA State Director. In 2020, I was offered a full-time role as Lead Technologist and joined the Leadership Team in 2024. The company went through several iterations during my time there, each bringing opportunities to work with amazing new people and innovative programs.Together, we accomplished things Iâ€™ll always be proud of.Led by some incredible program managers, we grew the wildly successful internship program, which has placed over 200 women and gender-diverse individuals in paid internships, and continues to place even more.I upskilled and led the full-stack development efforts for our internship placement platform/app, which centralised program data, automated many previously manual workflows, and provided easy interfaces for interns and hiring partners to manage their information.In just a few short months, we developed and released the School of Code for online coding education, seizing the opportunity to provide accessible learning during lockdowns.I taught hundreds of kids and adults through in-person workshops, code camps, tutor groups, and online sessions. One online workshop had over 400 attendees, we even crashed CodeSandbox ğŸ˜… I trained government employees to use Python for improving their workflows. I helped develop curriculums in C#, JavaScript, React.js, and Node.js. I facilitated panels, events, and webinarsâ€”including a session on the main stage at the Virtual Engineers Summit. Sadly, my role ended at the close of 2024. DEIB work is often underfunded, making it challenging to sustain engineering roles in this space. I get it. I'm grateful. Iâ€™ll always be part of this community. Code Like a Girl isnâ€™t just a company; itâ€™s a network, a movement, a heartbeat. I have met some of my dearest friends through Code Like a Girl. Iâ€™ll continue to show up as a community advocate, a mentor, and a fan.BUT a new adventure is beginning soon. Iâ€™m excited. ğŸ‘€ Watch this space.

I joined Code Like a Girl in 2018 after attending their inaugural Adelaide event, with hundreds of people crammed into a cosy venue. I was so energised by the vision that Ally Watson OAM had for the future of the tech industry. I started by putting in a few hours a week as Education Lead in South Australia, and my role soon evolved to SA State Director. In 2020, I was offered a full-time role as Lead Technologist and joined the Leadership Team in 2024. The company went through several iterations during my time there, each bringing opportunities to work with amazing new people and innovative programs.Together, we accomplished things Iâ€™ll always be proud of.Led by some incredible program managers, we grew the wildly successful internship program, which has placed over 200 women and gender-diverse individuals in paid internships, and continues to place even more.I upskilled and led the full-stack development efforts for our internship placement platform/app, which centralised program data, automated many previously manual workflows, and provided easy interfaces for interns and hiring partners to manage their information.In just a few short months, we developed and released the School of Code for online coding education, seizing the opportunity to provide accessible learning during lockdowns.I taught hundreds of kids and adults through in-person workshops, code camps, tutor groups, and online sessions. One online workshop had over 400 attendees, we even crashed CodeSandbox ğŸ˜… I trained government employees to use Python for improving their workflows. I helped develop curriculums in C#, JavaScript, React.js, and Node.js. I facilitated panels, events, and webinarsâ€”including a session on the main stage at the Virtual Engineers Summit. Sadly, my role ended at the close of 2024. DEIB work is often underfunded, making it challenging to sustain engineering roles in this space. I get it. I'm grateful. Iâ€™ll always be part of this community. Code Like a Girl isnâ€™t just a company; itâ€™s a network, a movement, a heartbeat. I have met some of my dearest friends through Code Like a Girl. Iâ€™ll continue to show up as a community advocate, a mentor, and a fan.BUT a new adventure is beginning soon. Iâ€™m excited. ğŸ‘€ Watch this space.

Username: TECO Electric & Machinery Co., Ltd.TECO Electric & Machinery Co., Ltd.
Post Content:
ğŸš€ TECO Acquires Malaysia's NCL Energy to Enter Southeast Asia's Data Center MEP Engineering Market ğŸŒExciting News! ğŸ‰ TECO has officially signed an acquisition agreement in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, with NCL Energy Sdn Bhd. By acquiring an 80% stake in NCL, TECO becomes the largest shareholder, marking a significant milestone in our expansion into Malaysia's MEP engineering market for data centers and renewable energy."This acquisition aligns with TECO's strategy of focusing on the Southeast Asian market and demonstrates our long-term commitment to the Malaysian market," said Chairman Li. With NCL's experienced team, TECO will swiftly obtain the necessary licenses and workforce. NCL founder Dato' Ng Keng Hiong expressed his honor in joining the TECO Group. I joined Code Like a Girl in 2018 after attending their inaugural Adelaide event, with hundreds of people crammed into a cosy venue. I was so energised by the vision that Ally Watson OAM had for the future of the tech industry. I started by putting in a few hours a week as Education Lead in South Australia, and my role soon evolved to SA State Director. In 2020, I was offered a full-time role as Lead Technologist and joined the Leadership Team in 2024. The company went through several iterations during my time there, each bringing opportunities to work with amazing new people and innovative programs.Together, we accomplished things Iâ€™ll always be proud of.Led by some incredible program managers, we grew the wildly successful internship program, which has placed over 200 women and gender-diverse individuals in paid internships, and continues to place even more.I upskilled and led the full-stack development efforts for our internship placement platform/app, which centralised program data, automated many previously manual workflows, and provided easy interfaces for interns and hiring partners to manage their information.In just a few short months, we developed and released the School of Code for online coding education, seizing the opportunity to provide accessible learning during lockdowns.I taught hundreds of kids and adults through in-person workshops, code camps, tutor groups, and online sessions. One online workshop had over 400 attendees, we even crashed CodeSandbox ğŸ˜… I trained government employees to use Python for improving their workflows. I helped develop curriculums in C#, JavaScript, React.js, and Node.js. I facilitated panels, events, and webinarsâ€”including a session on the main stage at the Virtual Engineers Summit. Sadly, my role ended at the close of 2024. DEIB work is often underfunded, making it challenging to sustain engineering roles in this space. I get it. I'm grateful. Iâ€™ll always be part of this community. Code Like a Girl isnâ€™t just a company; itâ€™s a network, a movement, a heartbeat. I have met some of my dearest friends through Code Like a Girl. Iâ€™ll continue to show up as a community advocate, a mentor, and a fan.BUT a new adventure is beginning soon. Iâ€™m excited. ğŸ‘€ Watch this space.

I joined Code Like a Girl in 2018 after attending their inaugural Adelaide event, with hundreds of people crammed into a cosy venue. I was so energised by the vision that Ally Watson OAM had for the future of the tech industry. I started by putting in a few hours a week as Education Lead in South Australia, and my role soon evolved to SA State Director. In 2020, I was offered a full-time role as Lead Technologist and joined the Leadership Team in 2024. The company went through several iterations during my time there, each bringing opportunities to work with amazing new people and innovative programs.Together, we accomplished things Iâ€™ll always be proud of.Led by some incredible program managers, we grew the wildly successful internship program, which has placed over 200 women and gender-diverse individuals in paid internships, and continues to place even more.I upskilled and led the full-stack development efforts for our internship placement platform/app, which centralised program data, automated many previously manual workflows, and provided easy interfaces for interns and hiring partners to manage their information.In just a few short months, we developed and released the School of Code for online coding education, seizing the opportunity to provide accessible learning during lockdowns.I taught hundreds of kids and adults through in-person workshops, code camps, tutor groups, and online sessions. One online workshop had over 400 attendees, we even crashed CodeSandbox ğŸ˜… I trained government employees to use Python for improving their workflows. I helped develop curriculums in C#, JavaScript, React.js, and Node.js. I facilitated panels, events, and webinarsâ€”including a session on the main stage at the Virtual Engineers Summit. Sadly, my role ended at the close of 2024. DEIB work is often underfunded, making it challenging to sustain engineering roles in this space. I get it. I'm grateful. Iâ€™ll always be part of this community. Code Like a Girl isnâ€™t just a company; itâ€™s a network, a movement, a heartbeat. I have met some of my dearest friends through Code Like a Girl. Iâ€™ll continue to show up as a community advocate, a mentor, and a fan.BUT a new adventure is beginning soon. Iâ€™m excited. ğŸ‘€ Watch this space.

ğŸš€ TECO Acquires Malaysia's NCL Energy to Enter Southeast Asia's Data Center MEP Engineering Market ğŸŒExciting News! ğŸ‰ TECO has officially signed an acquisition agreement in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, with NCL Energy Sdn Bhd. By acquiring an 80% stake in NCL, TECO becomes the largest shareholder, marking a significant milestone in our expansion into Malaysia's MEP engineering market for data centers and renewable energy."This acquisition aligns with TECO's strategy of focusing on the Southeast Asian market and demonstrates our long-term commitment to the Malaysian market," said Chairman Li. With NCL's experienced team, TECO will swiftly obtain the necessary licenses and workforce. NCL founder Dato' Ng Keng Hiong expressed his honor in joining the TECO Group. This investment not only recognizes NCL's management team but also aims to expand our capabilities in large-scale projects. TECO is excited to seize market opportunities and fulfill our vision of electrification, intelligence, and green energy in Southeast Asia. ğŸ’šğŸŒŸLast but not least, TECO is looking for talented individuals to join our team in Malaysia!ğŸŒŸ We are actively hiring for various positions in our Malaysia IDC market. I joined Code Like a Girl in 2018 after attending their inaugural Adelaide event, with hundreds of people crammed into a cosy venue. I was so energised by the vision that Ally Watson OAM had for the future of the tech industry. I started by putting in a few hours a week as Education Lead in South Australia, and my role soon evolved to SA State Director. In 2020, I was offered a full-time role as Lead Technologist and joined the Leadership Team in 2024. The company went through several iterations during my time there, each bringing opportunities to work with amazing new people and innovative programs.Together, we accomplished things Iâ€™ll always be proud of.Led by some incredible program managers, we grew the wildly successful internship program, which has placed over 200 women and gender-diverse individuals in paid internships, and continues to place even more.I upskilled and led the full-stack development efforts for our internship placement platform/app, which centralised program data, automated many previously manual workflows, and provided easy interfaces for interns and hiring partners to manage their information.In just a few short months, we developed and released the School of Code for online coding education, seizing the opportunity to provide accessible learning during lockdowns.I taught hundreds of kids and adults through in-person workshops, code camps, tutor groups, and online sessions. One online workshop had over 400 attendees, we even crashed CodeSandbox ğŸ˜… I trained government employees to use Python for improving their workflows. I helped develop curriculums in C#, JavaScript, React.js, and Node.js. I facilitated panels, events, and webinarsâ€”including a session on the main stage at the Virtual Engineers Summit. Sadly, my role ended at the close of 2024. DEIB work is often underfunded, making it challenging to sustain engineering roles in this space. I get it. I'm grateful. Iâ€™ll always be part of this community. Code Like a Girl isnâ€™t just a company; itâ€™s a network, a movement, a heartbeat. I have met some of my dearest friends through Code Like a Girl. Iâ€™ll continue to show up as a community advocate, a mentor, and a fan.BUT a new adventure is beginning soon. Iâ€™m excited. ğŸ‘€ Watch this space.

I joined Code Like a Girl in 2018 after attending their inaugural Adelaide event, with hundreds of people crammed into a cosy venue. I was so energised by the vision that Ally Watson OAM had for the future of the tech industry. I started by putting in a few hours a week as Education Lead in South Australia, and my role soon evolved to SA State Director. In 2020, I was offered a full-time role as Lead Technologist and joined the Leadership Team in 2024. The company went through several iterations during my time there, each bringing opportunities to work with amazing new people and innovative programs.Together, we accomplished things Iâ€™ll always be proud of.Led by some incredible program managers, we grew the wildly successful internship program, which has placed over 200 women and gender-diverse individuals in paid internships, and continues to place even more.I upskilled and led the full-stack development efforts for our internship placement platform/app, which centralised program data, automated many previously manual workflows, and provided easy interfaces for interns and hiring partners to manage their information.In just a few short months, we developed and released the School of Code for online coding education, seizing the opportunity to provide accessible learning during lockdowns.I taught hundreds of kids and adults through in-person workshops, code camps, tutor groups, and online sessions. One online workshop had over 400 attendees, we even crashed CodeSandbox ğŸ˜… I trained government employees to use Python for improving their workflows. I helped develop curriculums in C#, JavaScript, React.js, and Node.js. I facilitated panels, events, and webinarsâ€”including a session on the main stage at the Virtual Engineers Summit. Sadly, my role ended at the close of 2024. DEIB work is often underfunded, making it challenging to sustain engineering roles in this space. I get it. I'm grateful. Iâ€™ll always be part of this community. Code Like a Girl isnâ€™t just a company; itâ€™s a network, a movement, a heartbeat. I have met some of my dearest friends through Code Like a Girl. Iâ€™ll continue to show up as a community advocate, a mentor, and a fan.BUT a new adventure is beginning soon. Iâ€™m excited. ğŸ‘€ Watch this space.

I joined Code Like a Girl in 2018 after attending their inaugural Adelaide event, with hundreds of people crammed into a cosy venue. I was so energised by the vision that Ally Watson OAM had for the future of the tech industry. I started by putting in a few hours a week as Education Lead in South Australia, and my role soon evolved to SA State Director. In 2020, I was offered a full-time role as Lead Technologist and joined the Leadership Team in 2024. The company went through several iterations during my time there, each bringing opportunities to work with amazing new people and innovative programs.Together, we accomplished things Iâ€™ll always be proud of.Led by some incredible program managers, we grew the wildly successful internship program, which has placed over 200 women and gender-diverse individuals in paid internships, and continues to place even more.I upskilled and led the full-stack development efforts for our internship placement platform/app, which centralised program data, automated many previously manual workflows, and provided easy interfaces for interns and hiring partners to manage their information.In just a few short months, we developed and released the School of Code for online coding education, seizing the opportunity to provide accessible learning during lockdowns.I taught hundreds of kids and adults through in-person workshops, code camps, tutor groups, and online sessions. One online workshop had over 400 attendees, we even crashed CodeSandbox ğŸ˜… I trained government employees to use Python for improving their workflows. I helped develop curriculums in C#, JavaScript, React.js, and Node.js. I facilitated panels, events, and webinarsâ€”including a session on the main stage at the Virtual Engineers Summit. Sadly, my role ended at the close of 2024. DEIB work is often underfunded, making it challenging to sustain engineering roles in this space. I get it. I'm grateful. Iâ€™ll always be part of this community. Code Like a Girl isnâ€™t just a company; itâ€™s a network, a movement, a heartbeat. I have met some of my dearest friends through Code Like a Girl. Iâ€™ll continue to show up as a community advocate, a mentor, and a fan.BUT a new adventure is beginning soon. Iâ€™m excited. ğŸ‘€ Watch this space.

I joined Code Like a Girl in 2018 after attending their inaugural Adelaide event, with hundreds of people crammed into a cosy venue. I was so energised by the vision that Ally Watson OAM had for the future of the tech industry. I started by putting in a few hours a week as Education Lead in South Australia, and my role soon evolved to SA State Director. In 2020, I was offered a full-time role as Lead Technologist and joined the Leadership Team in 2024. The company went through several iterations during my time there, each bringing opportunities to work with amazing new people and innovative programs.Together, we accomplished things Iâ€™ll always be proud of.Led by some incredible program managers, we grew the wildly successful internship program, which has placed over 200 women and gender-diverse individuals in paid internships, and continues to place even more.I upskilled and led the full-stack development efforts for our internship placement platform/app, which centralised program data, automated many previously manual workflows, and provided easy interfaces for interns and hiring partners to manage their information.In just a few short months, we developed and released the School of Code for online coding education, seizing the opportunity to provide accessible learning during lockdowns.I taught hundreds of kids and adults through in-person workshops, code camps, tutor groups, and online sessions. One online workshop had over 400 attendees, we even crashed CodeSandbox ğŸ˜… I trained government employees to use Python for improving their workflows. I helped develop curriculums in C#, JavaScript, React.js, and Node.js. I facilitated panels, events, and webinarsâ€”including a session on the main stage at the Virtual Engineers Summit. Sadly, my role ended at the close of 2024. DEIB work is often underfunded, making it challenging to sustain engineering roles in this space. I get it. I'm grateful. Iâ€™ll always be part of this community. Code Like a Girl isnâ€™t just a company; itâ€™s a network, a movement, a heartbeat. I have met some of my dearest friends through Code Like a Girl. Iâ€™ll continue to show up as a community advocate, a mentor, and a fan.BUT a new adventure is beginning soon. Iâ€™m excited. ğŸ‘€ Watch this space.

Post Content:
End-to-End Data Engineering & Analytics with Azure + Power BIExcited to share my latest data engineering project implementing a cloud-based data lake house architecture using Azure services, designed a dynamic pipeline using Azure Data Factory(ADF).ğŸ›ï¸ This end-to end solution leverages a Medallion architecture[Bronze (raw)â†’ Silver (cleansed) â†’ Gold (reporting views)] to efficiently manage data ingestion(ADF), Transformation(Databricks) and processing.Here's a breakdown of the project:ğŸš€Optimized Storage with ADLS Gen2By utilizing Azure Data lake storage Gen2 with hierarchical namespace enabled, I ensured high-performance storage with enhance security and cost-efficiency, essential for managing structured data lake.ğŸ§©Automated Data Ingestion with ADFI created linked services, built a dynamic pipeline in Azure Data Factory using a ForEach loop to pull multiple CSV datasets from GitHub automatically into the bronze layer of ADLS GEN2 and parameters reading  from JSON configuration and applied  the dynamic workflow as data grows.âœ…PySpark Data TransformationsUtilizing PySpark for data transformations, I performed cleanup, filtering and aggregations to optimize incremental load and again write the data into sliver layer.âœ…Advanced Azure Synapse ImplementationServerless SQL pools querying directly from data lake, created external tables and  views using SQL scripts and designed a star schema with fact and dimension tables for optimized reporting and fast queries.ğŸ”’Data Governance and SecuritySecurity implementation with master key encryption and managed identities,integrated with IAM and storage blob contributor enabled data management and security for both structured and unstructured datasets and used SQL Endpoints to connect power BI and Synapse.ğŸ“ŠReporting & VisualizationConnected the Gold layer to power BI and created Dashboards.This Journey helped me strengthen my understanding of building scalable and modular data pipelines using cloud-native tools.GitHub Link:https://lnkd.in/ggDEtdziA special thanks to Ansh Lamba for  your time and effort in explaining the workflow in detail. It helped me connect the dots across data ingestion, transformation, and reporting.hashtag#DataEngineering hashtag#Azure hashtag#ADF hashtag#PowerBI hashtag#ETL hashtag#AdventureWorks hashtag#CloudData hashtag#AzureDataFactory hashtag#AzureSynapse hashtag#DataLakehouse hashtag#PowerBI hashtag#BusinessIntelligence

I joined Code Like a Girl in 2018 after attending their inaugural Adelaide event, with hundreds of people crammed into a cosy venue. I was so energised by the vision that Ally Watson OAM had for the future of the tech industry. I started by putting in a few hours a week as Education Lead in South Australia, and my role soon evolved to SA State Director. In 2020, I was offered a full-time role as Lead Technologist and joined the Leadership Team in 2024. The company went through several iterations during my time there, each bringing opportunities to work with amazing new people and innovative programs.Together, we accomplished things Iâ€™ll always be proud of.Led by some incredible program managers, we grew the wildly successful internship program, which has placed over 200 women and gender-diverse individuals in paid internships, and continues to place even more.I upskilled and led the full-stack development efforts for our internship placement platform/app, which centralised program data, automated many previously manual workflows, and provided easy interfaces for interns and hiring partners to manage their information.In just a few short months, we developed and released the School of Code for online coding education, seizing the opportunity to provide accessible learning during lockdowns.I taught hundreds of kids and adults through in-person workshops, code camps, tutor groups, and online sessions. One online workshop had over 400 attendees, we even crashed CodeSandbox ğŸ˜… I trained government employees to use Python for improving their workflows. I helped develop curriculums in C#, JavaScript, React.js, and Node.js. I facilitated panels, events, and webinarsâ€”including a session on the main stage at the Virtual Engineers Summit. Sadly, my role ended at the close of 2024. DEIB work is often underfunded, making it challenging to sustain engineering roles in this space. I get it. I'm grateful. Iâ€™ll always be part of this community. Code Like a Girl isnâ€™t just a company; itâ€™s a network, a movement, a heartbeat. I have met some of my dearest friends through Code Like a Girl. Iâ€™ll continue to show up as a community advocate, a mentor, and a fan.BUT a new adventure is beginning soon. Iâ€™m excited. ğŸ‘€ Watch this space.

Post Content:
End-to-End Data Engineering & Analytics with Azure + Power BIExcited to share my latest data engineering project implementing a cloud-based data lake house architecture using Azure services, designed a dynamic pipeline using Azure Data Factory(ADF).ğŸ›ï¸ This end-to end solution leverages a Medallion architecture[Bronze (raw)â†’ Silver (cleansed) â†’ Gold (reporting views)] to efficiently manage data ingestion(ADF), Transformation(Databricks) and processing.Here's a breakdown of the project:ğŸš€Optimized Storage with ADLS Gen2By utilizing Azure Data lake storage Gen2 with hierarchical namespace enabled, I ensured high-performance storage with enhance security and cost-efficiency, essential for managing structured data lake.ğŸ§©Automated Data Ingestion with ADFI created linked services, built a dynamic pipeline in Azure Data Factory using a ForEach loop to pull multiple CSV datasets from GitHub automatically into the bronze layer of ADLS GEN2 and parameters reading  from JSON configuration and applied  the dynamic workflow as data grows.âœ…PySpark Data TransformationsUtilizing PySpark for data transformations, I performed cleanup, filtering and aggregations to optimize incremental load and again write the data into sliver layer.âœ…Advanced Azure Synapse ImplementationServerless SQL pools querying directly from data lake, created external tables and  views using SQL scripts and designed a star schema with fact and dimension tables for optimized reporting and fast queries.ğŸ”’Data Governance and SecuritySecurity implementation with master key encryption and managed identities,integrated with IAM and storage blob contributor enabled data management and security for both structured and unstructured datasets and used SQL Endpoints to connect power BI and Synapse.ğŸ“ŠReporting & VisualizationConnected the Gold layer to power BI and created Dashboards.This Journey helped me strengthen my understanding of building scalable and modular data pipelines using cloud-native tools.GitHub Link:https://lnkd.in/ggDEtdziA special thanks to Ansh Lamba for  your time and effort in explaining the workflow in detail. It helped me connect the dots across data ingestion, transformation, and reporting.hashtag#DataEngineering hashtag#Azure hashtag#ADF hashtag#PowerBI hashtag#ETL hashtag#AdventureWorks hashtag#CloudData hashtag#AzureDataFactory hashtag#AzureSynapse hashtag#DataLakehouse hashtag#PowerBI hashtag#BusinessIntelligence

I joined Code Like a Girl in 2018 after attending their inaugural Adelaide event, with hundreds of people crammed into a cosy venue. I was so energised by the vision that Ally Watson OAM had for the future of the tech industry. I started by putting in a few hours a week as Education Lead in South Australia, and my role soon evolved to SA State Director. In 2020, I was offered a full-time role as Lead Technologist and joined the Leadership Team in 2024. The company went through several iterations during my time there, each bringing opportunities to work with amazing new people and innovative programs.Together, we accomplished things Iâ€™ll always be proud of.Led by some incredible program managers, we grew the wildly successful internship program, which has placed over 200 women and gender-diverse individuals in paid internships, and continues to place even more.I upskilled and led the full-stack development efforts for our internship placement platform/app, which centralised program data, automated many previously manual workflows, and provided easy interfaces for interns and hiring partners to manage their information.In just a few short months, we developed and released the School of Code for online coding education, seizing the opportunity to provide accessible learning during lockdowns.I taught hundreds of kids and adults through in-person workshops, code camps, tutor groups, and online sessions. One online workshop had over 400 attendees, we even crashed CodeSandbox ğŸ˜… I trained government employees to use Python for improving their workflows. I helped develop curriculums in C#, JavaScript, React.js, and Node.js. I facilitated panels, events, and webinarsâ€”including a session on the main stage at the Virtual Engineers Summit. Sadly, my role ended at the close of 2024. DEIB work is often underfunded, making it challenging to sustain engineering roles in this space. I get it. I'm grateful. Iâ€™ll always be part of this community. Code Like a Girl isnâ€™t just a company; itâ€™s a network, a movement, a heartbeat. I have met some of my dearest friends through Code Like a Girl. Iâ€™ll continue to show up as a community advocate, a mentor, and a fan.BUT a new adventure is beginning soon. Iâ€™m excited. ğŸ‘€ Watch this space.

Post Content:
End-to-End Data Engineering & Analytics with Azure + Power BIExcited to share my latest data engineering project implementing a cloud-based data lake house architecture using Azure services, designed a dynamic pipeline using Azure Data Factory(ADF).ğŸ›ï¸ This end-to end solution leverages a Medallion architecture[Bronze (raw)â†’ Silver (cleansed) â†’ Gold (reporting views)] to efficiently manage data ingestion(ADF), Transformation(Databricks) and processing.Here's a breakdown of the project:ğŸš€Optimized Storage with ADLS Gen2By utilizing Azure Data lake storage Gen2 with hierarchical namespace enabled, I ensured high-performance storage with enhance security and cost-efficiency, essential for managing structured data lake.ğŸ§©Automated Data Ingestion with ADFI created linked services, built a dynamic pipeline in Azure Data Factory using a ForEach loop to pull multiple CSV datasets from GitHub automatically into the bronze layer of ADLS GEN2 and parameters reading  from JSON configuration and applied  the dynamic workflow as data grows.âœ…PySpark Data TransformationsUtilizing PySpark for data transformations, I performed cleanup, filtering and aggregations to optimize incremental load and again write the data into sliver layer.âœ…Advanced Azure Synapse ImplementationServerless SQL pools querying directly from data lake, created external tables and  views using SQL scripts and designed a star schema with fact and dimension tables for optimized reporting and fast queries.ğŸ”’Data Governance and SecuritySecurity implementation with master key encryption and managed identities,integrated with IAM and storage blob contributor enabled data management and security for both structured and unstructured datasets and used SQL Endpoints to connect power BI and Synapse.ğŸ“ŠReporting & VisualizationConnected the Gold layer to power BI and created Dashboards.This Journey helped me strengthen my understanding of building scalable and modular data pipelines using cloud-native tools.GitHub Link:https://lnkd.in/ggDEtdziA special thanks to Ansh Lamba for  your time and effort in explaining the workflow in detail. It helped me connect the dots across data ingestion, transformation, and reporting.hashtag#DataEngineering hashtag#Azure hashtag#ADF hashtag#PowerBI hashtag#ETL hashtag#AdventureWorks hashtag#CloudData hashtag#AzureDataFactory hashtag#AzureSynapse hashtag#DataLakehouse hashtag#PowerBI hashtag#BusinessIntelligence

ğŸš€ TECO Acquires Malaysia's NCL Energy to Enter Southeast Asia's Data Center MEP Engineering Market ğŸŒExciting News! ğŸ‰ TECO has officially signed an acquisition agreement in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, with NCL Energy Sdn Bhd. By acquiring an 80% stake in NCL, TECO becomes the largest shareholder, marking a significant milestone in our expansion into Malaysia's MEP engineering market for data centers and renewable energy."This acquisition aligns with TECO's strategy of focusing on the Southeast Asian market and demonstrates our long-term commitment to the Malaysian market," said Chairman Li. With NCL's experienced team, TECO will swiftly obtain the necessary licenses and workforce. NCL founder Dato' Ng Keng Hiong expressed his honor in joining the TECO Group. This investment not only recognizes NCL's management team but also aims to expand our capabilities in large-scale projects. TECO is excited to seize market opportunities and fulfill our vision of electrification, intelligence, and green energy in Southeast Asia. ğŸ’šğŸŒŸLast but not least, TECO is looking for talented individuals to join our team in Malaysia!ğŸŒŸ We are actively hiring for various positions in our Malaysia IDC market. I joined Code Like a Girl in 2018 after attending their inaugural Adelaide event, with hundreds of people crammed into a cosy venue. I was so energised by the vision that Ally Watson OAM had for the future of the tech industry. I started by putting in a few hours a week as Education Lead in South Australia, and my role soon evolved to SA State Director. In 2020, I was offered a full-time role as Lead Technologist and joined the Leadership Team in 2024. The company went through several iterations during my time there, each bringing opportunities to work with amazing new people and innovative programs.Together, we accomplished things Iâ€™ll always be proud of.Led by some incredible program managers, we grew the wildly successful internship program, which has placed over 200 women and gender-diverse individuals in paid internships, and continues to place even more.I upskilled and led the full-stack development efforts for our internship placement platform/app, which centralised program data, automated many previously manual workflows, and provided easy interfaces for interns and hiring partners to manage their information.In just a few short months, we developed and released the School of Code for online coding education, seizing the opportunity to provide accessible learning during lockdowns.I taught hundreds of kids and adults through in-person workshops, code camps, tutor groups, and online sessions. One online workshop had over 400 attendees, we even crashed CodeSandbox ğŸ˜… I trained government employees to use Python for improving their workflows. I helped develop curriculums in C#, JavaScript, React.js, and Node.js. I facilitated panels, events, and webinarsâ€”including a session on the main stage at the Virtual Engineers Summit. Sadly, my role ended at the close of 2024. DEIB work is often underfunded, making it challenging to sustain engineering roles in this space. I get it. I'm grateful. Iâ€™ll always be part of this community. Code Like a Girl isnâ€™t just a company; itâ€™s a network, a movement, a heartbeat. I have met some of my dearest friends through Code Like a Girl. Iâ€™ll continue to show up as a community advocate, a mentor, and a fan.BUT a new adventure is beginning soon. Iâ€™m excited. ğŸ‘€ Watch this space.

a dynamic pipeline using Azure Data Factory(ADF).ğŸ›ï¸ This end-to end solution leverages a Medallion architecture[Bronze (raw)â†’ Silver (cleansed) â†’ Gold (reporting views)] to efficiently manage data ingestion(ADF), Transformation(Databricks) and processing.Here's a breakdown of the project:ğŸš€Optimized Storage with ADLS Gen2By utilizing Azure Data lake storage Gen2 with hierarchical namespace enabled, I ensured high-performance storage with enhance security and cost-efficiency, essential for managing structured data lake.ğŸ§©Automated Data Ingestion with ADFI created linked services, built a dynamic pipeline in Azure Data Factory using a ForEach loop to pull multiple CSV datasets from GitHub automatically into the bronze layer of ADLS GEN2 and parameters reading  from JSON configuration and applied  the dynamic workflow as data grows.âœ…PySpark Data TransformationsUtilizing PySpark for data transformations, I performed cleanup, filtering and aggregations to optimize incremental load and again write the data into sliver layer.âœ…Advanced Azure Synapse ImplementationServerless SQL pools querying directly from data lake, created external tables and  views using SQL scripts and designed a star schema with fact and dimension tables for optimized reporting and fast queries.ğŸ”’Data Governance and SecuritySecurity implementation with master key encryption and managed identities,integrated with IAM and storage blob contributor enabled data management and security for both structured and unstructured datasets and used SQL Endpoints to connect power BI and Synapse.ğŸ“ŠReporting & VisualizationConnected the Gold layer to power BI and created Dashboards.This Journey helped me strengthen my understanding of building scalable and modular data pipelines using cloud-native tools.GitHub Link:https://lnkd.in/ggDEtdziA special thanks to Ansh Lamba for  your time and effort in explaining the workflow in detail. I joined Code Like a Girl in 2018 after attending their inaugural Adelaide event, with hundreds of people crammed into a cosy venue. I was so energised by the vision that Ally Watson OAM had for the future of the tech industry. I started by putting in a few hours a week as Education Lead in South Australia, and my role soon evolved to SA State Director. In 2020, I was offered a full-time role as Lead Technologist and joined the Leadership Team in 2024. The company went through several iterations during my time there, each bringing opportunities to work with amazing new people and innovative programs.Together, we accomplished things Iâ€™ll always be proud of.Led by some incredible program managers, we grew the wildly successful internship program, which has placed over 200 women and gender-diverse individuals in paid internships, and continues to place even more.I upskilled and led the full-stack development efforts for our internship placement platform/app, which centralised program data, automated many previously manual workflows, and provided easy interfaces for interns and hiring partners to manage their information.In just a few short months, we developed and released the School of Code for online coding education, seizing the opportunity to provide accessible learning during lockdowns.I taught hundreds of kids and adults through in-person workshops, code camps, tutor groups, and online sessions. One online workshop had over 400 attendees, we even crashed CodeSandbox ğŸ˜… I trained government employees to use Python for improving their workflows. I helped develop curriculums in C#, JavaScript, React.js, and Node.js. I facilitated panels, events, and webinarsâ€”including a session on the main stage at the Virtual Engineers Summit. Sadly, my role ended at the close of 2024. DEIB work is often underfunded, making it challenging to sustain engineering roles in this space. I get it. I'm grateful. Iâ€™ll always be part of this community. Code Like a Girl isnâ€™t just a company; itâ€™s a network, a movement, a heartbeat. I have met some of my dearest friends through Code Like a Girl. Iâ€™ll continue to show up as a community advocate, a mentor, and a fan.BUT a new adventure is beginning soon. Iâ€™m excited. ğŸ‘€ Watch this space.

Hi LinkedIn! Exciting news to share with you all.Last you heard of me I was working at WiseTech alongside some of the best and brightest people in the industry. a dynamic pipeline using Azure Data Factory(ADF).ğŸ›ï¸ This end-to end solution leverages a Medallion architecture[Bronze (raw)â†’ Silver (cleansed) â†’ Gold (reporting views)] to efficiently manage data ingestion(ADF), Transformation(Databricks) and processing.Here's a breakdown of the project:ğŸš€Optimized Storage with ADLS Gen2By utilizing Azure Data lake storage Gen2 with hierarchical namespace enabled, I ensured high-performance storage with enhance security and cost-efficiency, essential for managing structured data lake.ğŸ§©Automated Data Ingestion with ADFI created linked services, built a dynamic pipeline in Azure Data Factory using a ForEach loop to pull multiple CSV datasets from GitHub automatically into the bronze layer of ADLS GEN2 and parameters reading  from JSON configuration and applied  the dynamic workflow as data grows.âœ…PySpark Data TransformationsUtilizing PySpark for data transformations, I performed cleanup, filtering and aggregations to optimize incremental load and again write the data into sliver layer.âœ…Advanced Azure Synapse ImplementationServerless SQL pools querying directly from data lake, created external tables and  views using SQL scripts and designed a star schema with fact and dimension tables for optimized reporting and fast queries.ğŸ”’Data Governance and SecuritySecurity implementation with master key encryption and managed identities,integrated with IAM and storage blob contributor enabled data management and security for both structured and unstructured datasets and used SQL Endpoints to connect power BI and Synapse.ğŸ“ŠReporting & VisualizationConnected the Gold layer to power BI and created Dashboards.This Journey helped me strengthen my understanding of building scalable and modular data pipelines using cloud-native tools.GitHub Link:https://lnkd.in/ggDEtdziA special thanks to Ansh Lamba for  your time and effort in explaining the workflow in detail. My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer

I joined Code Like a Girl in 2018 after attending their inaugural Adelaide event, with hundreds of people crammed into a cosy venue. I was so energised by the vision that Ally Watson OAM had for the future of the tech industry. I started by putting in a few hours a week as Education Lead in South Australia, and my role soon evolved to SA State Director. In 2020, I was offered a full-time role as Lead Technologist and joined the Leadership Team in 2024. The company went through several iterations during my time there, each bringing opportunities to work with amazing new people and innovative programs.Together, we accomplished things Iâ€™ll always be proud of.Led by some incredible program managers, we grew the wildly successful internship program, which has placed over 200 women and gender-diverse individuals in paid internships, and continues to place even more.I upskilled and led the full-stack development efforts for our internship placement platform/app, which centralised program data, automated many previously manual workflows, and provided easy interfaces for interns and hiring partners to manage their information.In just a few short months, we developed and released the School of Code for online coding education, seizing the opportunity to provide accessible learning during lockdowns.I taught hundreds of kids and adults through in-person workshops, code camps, tutor groups, and online sessions. One online workshop had over 400 attendees, we even crashed CodeSandbox ğŸ˜… I trained government employees to use Python for improving their workflows. I helped develop curriculums in C#, JavaScript, React.js, and Node.js. I facilitated panels, events, and webinarsâ€”including a session on the main stage at the Virtual Engineers Summit. Sadly, my role ended at the close of 2024. DEIB work is often underfunded, making it challenging to sustain engineering roles in this space. I get it. I'm grateful. Iâ€™ll always be part of this community. Code Like a Girl isnâ€™t just a company; itâ€™s a network, a movement, a heartbeat. I have met some of my dearest friends through Code Like a Girl. Iâ€™ll continue to show up as a community advocate, a mentor, and a fan.BUT a new adventure is beginning soon. Iâ€™m excited. ğŸ‘€ Watch this space.

End-to-End Data Engineering & Analytics with Azure + Power BIExcited to share my latest data engineering project implementing a cloud-based data lake house architecture using Azure services, designed a dynamic pipeline using Azure Data Factory(ADF).ğŸ›ï¸ This end-to end solution leverages a Medallion architecture[Bronze (raw)â†’ Silver (cleansed) â†’ Gold (reporting views)] to efficiently manage data ingestion(ADF), Transformation(Databricks) and processing.Here's a breakdown of the project:ğŸš€Optimized Storage with ADLS Gen2By utilizing Azure Data lake storage Gen2 with hierarchical namespace enabled, I ensured high-performance storage with enhance security and cost-efficiency, essential for managing structured data lake.ğŸ§©Automated Data Ingestion with ADFI created linked services, built a dynamic pipeline in Azure Data Factory using a ForEach loop to pull multiple CSV datasets from GitHub automatically into the bronze layer of ADLS GEN2 and parameters reading  from JSON configuration and applied  the dynamic workflow as data grows.âœ…PySpark Data TransformationsUtilizing PySpark for data transformations, I performed cleanup, filtering and aggregations to optimize incremental load and again write the data into sliver layer.âœ…Advanced Azure Synapse ImplementationServerless SQL pools querying directly from data lake, created external tables and  views using SQL scripts and designed a star schema with fact and dimension tables for optimized reporting and fast queries.ğŸ”’Data Governance and SecuritySecurity implementation with master key encryption and managed identities,integrated with IAM and storage blob contributor enabled data management and security for both structured and unstructured datasets and used SQL Endpoints to connect power BI and Synapse.ğŸ“ŠReporting & VisualizationConnected the Gold layer to power BI and created Dashboards.This Journey helped me strengthen my understanding of building scalable and modular data pipelines using cloud-native tools.GitHub Link:https://lnkd.in/ggDEtdziA special thanks to Ansh Lamba for  your time and effort in explaining the workflow in detail. My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer

I joined Code Like a Girl in 2018 after attending their inaugural Adelaide event, with hundreds of people crammed into a cosy venue. I was so energised by the vision that Ally Watson OAM had for the future of the tech industry. I started by putting in a few hours a week as Education Lead in South Australia, and my role soon evolved to SA State Director. In 2020, I was offered a full-time role as Lead Technologist and joined the Leadership Team in 2024. The company went through several iterations during my time there, each bringing opportunities to work with amazing new people and innovative programs.Together, we accomplished things Iâ€™ll always be proud of.Led by some incredible program managers, we grew the wildly successful internship program, which has placed over 200 women and gender-diverse individuals in paid internships, and continues to place even more.I upskilled and led the full-stack development efforts for our internship placement platform/app, which centralised program data, automated many previously manual workflows, and provided easy interfaces for interns and hiring partners to manage their information.In just a few short months, we developed and released the School of Code for online coding education, seizing the opportunity to provide accessible learning during lockdowns.I taught hundreds of kids and adults through in-person workshops, code camps, tutor groups, and online sessions. One online workshop had over 400 attendees, we even crashed CodeSandbox ğŸ˜… I trained government employees to use Python for improving their workflows. I helped develop curriculums in C#, JavaScript, React.js, and Node.js. I facilitated panels, events, and webinarsâ€”including a session on the main stage at the Virtual Engineers Summit. Sadly, my role ended at the close of 2024. DEIB work is often underfunded, making it challenging to sustain engineering roles in this space. I get it. I'm grateful. Iâ€™ll always be part of this community. Code Like a Girl isnâ€™t just a company; itâ€™s a network, a movement, a heartbeat. I have met some of my dearest friends through Code Like a Girl. Iâ€™ll continue to show up as a community advocate, a mentor, and a fan.BUT a new adventure is beginning soon. Iâ€™m excited. ğŸ‘€ Watch this space.

Hi LinkedIn! Exciting news to share with you all.Last you heard of me I was working at WiseTech alongside some of the best and brightest people in the industry. My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer

I joined Code Like a Girl in 2018 after attending their inaugural Adelaide event, with hundreds of people crammed into a cosy venue. I was so energised by the vision that Ally Watson OAM had for the future of the tech industry. I started by putting in a few hours a week as Education Lead in South Australia, and my role soon evolved to SA State Director. In 2020, I was offered a full-time role as Lead Technologist and joined the Leadership Team in 2024. The company went through several iterations during my time there, each bringing opportunities to work with amazing new people and innovative programs.Together, we accomplished things Iâ€™ll always be proud of.Led by some incredible program managers, we grew the wildly successful internship program, which has placed over 200 women and gender-diverse individuals in paid internships, and continues to place even more.I upskilled and led the full-stack development efforts for our internship placement platform/app, which centralised program data, automated many previously manual workflows, and provided easy interfaces for interns and hiring partners to manage their information.In just a few short months, we developed and released the School of Code for online coding education, seizing the opportunity to provide accessible learning during lockdowns.I taught hundreds of kids and adults through in-person workshops, code camps, tutor groups, and online sessions. One online workshop had over 400 attendees, we even crashed CodeSandbox ğŸ˜… I trained government employees to use Python for improving their workflows. I helped develop curriculums in C#, JavaScript, React.js, and Node.js. I facilitated panels, events, and webinarsâ€”including a session on the main stage at the Virtual Engineers Summit. Sadly, my role ended at the close of 2024. DEIB work is often underfunded, making it challenging to sustain engineering roles in this space. I get it. I'm grateful. Iâ€™ll always be part of this community. Code Like a Girl isnâ€™t just a company; itâ€™s a network, a movement, a heartbeat. I have met some of my dearest friends through Code Like a Girl. Iâ€™ll continue to show up as a community advocate, a mentor, and a fan.BUT a new adventure is beginning soon. Iâ€™m excited. ğŸ‘€ Watch this space.

a dynamic pipeline using Azure Data Factory(ADF).ğŸ›ï¸ This end-to end solution leverages a Medallion architecture[Bronze (raw)â†’ Silver (cleansed) â†’ Gold (reporting views)] to efficiently manage data ingestion(ADF), Transformation(Databricks) and processing.Here's a breakdown of the project:ğŸš€Optimized Storage with ADLS Gen2By utilizing Azure Data lake storage Gen2 with hierarchical namespace enabled, I ensured high-performance storage with enhance security and cost-efficiency, essential for managing structured data lake.ğŸ§©Automated Data Ingestion with ADFI created linked JSON configuration and applied  the dynamic workflow as data grows.âœ…PySpark Data TransformationsUtilizing PySpark for data transformations, I performed cleanup, filtering and aggregations to My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. I joined Code Like a Girl in 2018 after attending their inaugural Adelaide event, with hundreds of people crammed into a cosy venue. I was so energised by the vision that Ally Watson OAM had for the future of the tech industry. I started by putting in a few hours a week as Education Lead in South Australia, and my role soon evolved to SA State Director. In 2020, I was offered a full-time role as Lead Technologist and joined the Leadership Team in 2024. The company went through several iterations during my time there, each bringing opportunities to work with amazing new people and innovative programs.Together, we accomplished things Iâ€™ll always be proud of.Led by some incredible program managers, we grew the wildly successful internship program, which has placed over 200 women and gender-diverse individuals in paid internships, and continues to place even more.I upskilled and led the full-stack development efforts for our internship placement platform/app, which centralised program data, automated many previously manual workflows, and provided easy interfaces for interns and hiring partners to manage their information.In just a few short months, we developed and released the School of Code for online coding education, seizing the opportunity to provide accessible learning during lockdowns.I taught hundreds of kids and adults through in-person workshops, code camps, tutor groups, and online sessions. One online workshop had over 400 attendees, we even crashed CodeSandbox ğŸ˜… I trained government employees to use Python for improving their workflows. I helped develop curriculums in C#, JavaScript, React.js, and Node.js. I facilitated panels, events, and webinarsâ€”including a session on the main stage at the Virtual Engineers Summit. Sadly, my role ended at the close of 2024. DEIB work is often underfunded, making it challenging to sustain engineering roles in this space. I get it. I'm grateful. Iâ€™ll always be part of this community. Code Like a Girl isnâ€™t just a company; itâ€™s a network, a movement, a heartbeat. I have met some of my dearest friends through Code Like a Girl. Iâ€™ll continue to show up as a community advocate, a mentor, and a fan.BUT a new adventure is beginning soon. Iâ€™m excited. ğŸ‘€ Watch this space.

Post Content:
End-to-End Data Engineering & Analytics with Azure + Power BIExcited to share my latest data engineering project implementing a cloud-based data lake house architecture using Azure services, designed a dynamic pipeline using Azure Data Factory(ADF).ğŸ›ï¸ This end-to end solution leverages a Medallion architecture[Bronze (raw)â†’ Silver (cleansed) â†’ Gold (reporting views)] to efficiently manage data ingestion(ADF), Transformation(Databricks) and processing.Here's a breakdown of the project:ğŸš€Optimized Storage with ADLS Gen2By utilizing Azure Data lake storage Gen2 with hierarchical namespace enabled, I ensured high-performance storage with enhance security and cost-efficiency, essential for managing structured data lake.ğŸ§©Automated Data Ingestion with ADFI created linked services, built a dynamic pipeline in Azure Data Factory using a ForEach loop to pull multiple CSV datasets from GitHub automatically into the bronze layer of ADLS GEN2 and parameters reading  from JSON configuration and applied  the dynamic workflow as data grows.âœ…PySpark Data TransformationsUtilizing PySpark for data transformations, I performed cleanup, filtering and aggregations to optimize incremental load and again write the data into sliver layer.âœ…Advanced Azure Synapse ImplementationServerless SQL pools querying directly from data lake, created external tables and  views using SQL scripts and designed a star schema with fact and dimension tables for optimized reporting and fast queries.ğŸ”’Data Governance and SecuritySecurity implementation with master key encryption and managed identities,integrated with IAM and storage blob contributor enabled data management and security for both structured and unstructured datasets and used SQL Endpoints to connect power BI and Synapse.ğŸ“ŠReporting & VisualizationConnected the Gold layer to power BI and created Dashboards.This Journey helped me strengthen my understanding of building scalable and modular data pipelines using cloud-native tools.GitHub Link:https://lnkd.in/ggDEtdziA special thanks to Ansh Lamba for  your time and effort in explaining the workflow in detail. It helped me connect the dots across data ingestion, transformation, and reporting.hashtag#DataEngineering hashtag#Azure hashtag#ADF hashtag#PowerBI hashtag#ETL hashtag#AdventureWorks hashtag#CloudData hashtag#AzureDataFactory hashtag#AzureSynapse hashtag#DataLakehouse hashtag#PowerBI hashtag#BusinessIntelligence

My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer

Engineers on H-1B and L-1 visas fear US restrictions will limit opportunities, yet this shift could empower global talent to drive energy innovation.Experts say the federal government can't change visa caps, but they can tighten the process.So, energy companies sponsoring visas may experience longer waits and increased denials.Engineers on H-1B and L-1 visas fear US restrictions will limit opportunities, yet this shift could empower global talent to drive energy innovation.Experts say the federal government can't change visa caps, but they can tighten the process. So, energy companies sponsoring visas may experience longer waits and increased denials.Having navigated these waters myself, from being a Masterâ€™s student to OPT to H1B to Green Card and being an Entrepreneur now, I know the uncertainty this creates for both talented professionals and the companies investing in them.Immigration policy is still a big question mark.Emerging technologies like AI/ML, Big data, Digital Twin, Cyber Security etc.. are no more alien terms for modern grid, and all these Tech run on worldwide talent. No way around it.Tech companies keeps ramping up global hiring, despite calls for restrictions.(Tesla's H-1B numbers shot up to 700+ in 2024.)Critics accuse companies of exploiting the visa system for cheap foreign talent to pad profits.Sure, economic arbitrage is real.But so is the US energy sector's looming 80,000-worker shortage by 2030.(No talent to innovate smart grids, modernization, or renewables.)More than 25% of the US's electrical engineers are foreign.The country needs H-1B and L-1 visa talent to maintain its competitive edge.If US visa restrictions tighten, companies will likely â€œparkâ€ staff in immigration-friendly countries.Opportunities exist well beyond any single market.Though not ideal, international talent can also accelerate clean energy development in Europe, Asia, and Africa.Right now, it's difficult to predict anything.Meanwhile, companies hiring H-1B and L-1 talent in the US should brace for increased legal fees and new compliance requirements.Do you think this is a watershed moment for international talent in the US or just political theater?Sources: Sources: NPR, S&P Global, and Power TechnologyVideo Credit: Business Standardâš¡ Follow me for no-nonsense insights on power systems, protection engineering, and the energy transition.

I joined Code Like a Girl in 2018 after attending their inaugural Adelaide event, with hundreds of people crammed into a cosy venue. I was so energised by the vision that Ally Watson OAM had for the future of the tech industry. I started by putting in a few hours a week as Education Lead in South Australia, and my role soon evolved to SA State Director. In 2020, I was offered a full-time role as Lead Technologist and joined the Leadership Team in 2024. The company went through several iterations during my time there, each bringing opportunities to work with amazing new people and innovative programs.Together, we accomplished things Iâ€™ll always be proud of.Led by some incredible program managers, we grew the wildly successful internship program, which has placed over 200 women and gender-diverse individuals in paid internships, and continues to place even more.I upskilled and led the full-stack development efforts for our internship placement platform/app, which centralised program data, automated many previously manual workflows, and provided easy interfaces for interns and hiring partners to manage their information.In just a few short months, we developed and released the School of Code for online coding education, seizing the opportunity to provide accessible learning during lockdowns.I taught hundreds of kids and adults through in-person workshops, code camps, tutor groups, and online sessions. One online workshop had over 400 attendees, we even crashed CodeSandbox ğŸ˜… I trained government employees to use Python for improving their workflows. I helped develop curriculums in C#, JavaScript, React.js, and Node.js. I facilitated panels, events, and webinarsâ€”including a session on the main stage at the Virtual Engineers Summit. Sadly, my role ended at the close of 2024. DEIB work is often underfunded, making it challenging to sustain engineering roles in this space. I get it. I'm grateful. Iâ€™ll always be part of this community. Code Like a Girl isnâ€™t just a company; itâ€™s a network, a movement, a heartbeat. I have met some of my dearest friends through Code Like a Girl. Iâ€™ll continue to show up as a community advocate, a mentor, and a fan.BUT a new adventure is beginning soon. Iâ€™m excited. ğŸ‘€ Watch this space.

My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer
